questions.text: What is the active principle of the image shown below?
questions.solution:
Seeds of Semicarpus anacardium, and its active principles are bhilawanol and semicarpol.

  • Common names are marking nut, bhilwan, bibva, and oriental cashew.
  • The image shows black, heart-shaped seeds with hard rinds that identify them as seeds of S. anacardium. Within the fruit is a thick fleshy pericarp that yields the active principle, which is a brown oily resinous fluid called bhilawanol.
  • The juice when applied locally to the skin produces irritation, painful blisters, itching, and eczematous eruption. The seeds are used to produce an artificial bruise.
  • Symptoms such as pain, fever, and painful passage of brownish urine may be seen.

Other Options:

Option A - Abrin - Also known as gunchi, rati, sui; resembles viper/snake bite.

Option C - Calotropin - It is also known as akar and madar; Active principle is uscharin and calotoxin.

Option D - Ricin - It is a toxalbumin in Ricinus communis, also known as arandi.

It is a biological warfare agent (Category B)

KEY TAKEAWAY: Active principle of Semicarpus anacardium is bhilwanol.

CLINICAL RELEVANCE: Medicolegal importance is the use of the juice by malingerers to fabricate wounds. Instilled in the eyes it can cause conjunctivitis or ophthalmia due to its local irritant effect.

TAGLINE - EASY

Rrference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page number: 556

questions.text: A 45-year-old psychiatric patient consumed some liquid from a bottle accidentally. Clinical examination shows a peculiar rash as shown in the image. What is the likely cause of this presentation?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the characteristic boiled lobster appearance of Boric acid poisoning.

  • It represents generalised desquamation and erythema.
  • Rashes are seen commonly in palms, soles, and buttocks.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Oxalic acid - Typically presents with hypocalcemia; known as acid of sugar/salt of sorrel.

Option B-Hydrochloric acid - Also known as muriatic acid, it is a less corrosive acid hence perforation of stomach, corrosion of skin are rare.

Option-D-Carbolic acid -

TIPS AND TRICK - 3 C's - Constriction of pupil Deposition in cartilage - ochronosis Causes Carboluria - dark green colored urine

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The characteristic boiled lobster appearance of Boric acid poisoning.

TAGLINE - MODERATE

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page number: 534

questions.text: Identify the type of skull fracture in the given image?
questions.solution:
Depressed fracture

  • Depressed fracture is also known as signature fracture.
  • Caused by an object with large amount of kinetic energy and small striking surface area.
  • Pattern of fracture often resembles the weapon or agent causing it.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ring fracture - Seen when someone falls from height and lands on ground.

It is seen around foramen magnum.

Option C - Fissured fracture - Also known as linear fracture, it is the most common type of skull fracture. Caused by blow with a broad striking surface.

Option D - Comminuted fracture - Also known a spider web fracture.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Depressed fracture is also known as signature fracture.

Caused by an object with large amount of kinetic energy and small striking surface area.

TAGLINE - EASY

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page number: 244, 245, 246

questions.text: A 33-year-old patient is being evaluated for longstanding anemia. On clinical examination, you notice the given finding. Which of the following metal poisoning is associated with this characteristic finding?
questions.solution:
The image is showing characteristic Burtonian lines, which are associated with lead poisoning.

These are bluish-grey lead lines that occur with chronic exposure to lead poisoning.

  • Lead inhibits ALA Dehydratase and ferrochelatase resulting in microcytic hypochromic anemia.
  • TIPS AND TRICK for lead poisoning:
    • A-Anemia
    • B-Basophilic stippling
    • C-Colic and constipation "Lead leads to lead lines":
    • D-Drops-wrist drop
    • E-Encephalopathy
    • F-Facial pallor (earliest feature)

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Thallium - Alopecia, skin rash and painful peripheral neuropathy.

Characteristic of thallium poisoning - Loss of outer 2/3 of eyebrows.

Option B - Arsenic poisoning - Presents with

  • Raindrop pigmentation
  • Hyperkeratosis of palms and soles
  • Aldrich mees lines and garlic odour of breath, alopecia etc.

Option D - Berylliosis - It doesn't present with Burtonian lines.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Burtonian lines are associated with lead poisoning.

TAGLINE - MODERATE

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page number: 544, 545

questions.text: A 43-year-old man working in the mining industry presents with painful paraesthesias of his hands and feet. Examination of the limbs reveals the following findings. Which of the following is the drug of choice for his condition?
questions.solution:
The given images (raindrop pigmentation and Mees lines) along with the clinical features are suggestive of chronic arsenic poisoning.

Chelation therapy for subacute or chronic severe arsenic toxicity is succimer (DMSA).

TIPS AND TRICK - ARSENIC

  • A-Abortion
    Aldrich     mees lines
  • R-Red velvety mucosa
    Raindrop pigmentation
    Reinsch test/marsh test
  • S-Subendocardial hemorrhage
  • E-Excessive pigmentation of palm and soles
  • N-Neuropathy
  • I-Iron oxide used in gastric lavage
  • C-Mimics Cholera

The other 3 options - A, C and D are incorrect.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Chelation therapy for subacute or chronic severe arsenic toxicity is succimer (DMSA).

For acute arsenic toxicity, the following can be used:

  • BAL (British anti-Lewisite)
  • DMSA (Dimercaptosuccinic acid)
  • DMPS (Dimercaptopropane-1-sulfonate)

BAL tends to remain the initial chelating drug for severe, acute arsenic toxicity.

TAGLINE: MODERATE

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page number: 538, 539

questions.text: Postmortem marbling becomes prominent at what time?
questions.solution:
The given picture shows postmortem marbling. It starts in 24 hours and becomes prominent in 36-48 hours.

  • The blood in the vessels is haemolysed, which stains the vessel walls and the adjacent tissues, giving rise to a marbled appearance.
  • It is greenish-brown or purplish-red discoloration of superficial veins due to the formation of sulphmethemoglobin, which diffuses into tissues.
  • It is distinctly appreciable on the abdomen, shoulders, chest, and inguinal region.

Options A, B and D are incorrect.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Postmortem marbling, starts in 24 hours and becomes prominent in 36-48 hours.

TAGLINE: EASY

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page number:165

questions.text: The image given below is a type of ______.
questions.solution:
• A contusion is characterized by the infiltration of extravasated blood into the subcutaneous and/or subepithelial tissues. It results from the rupture of small blood vessels due to the application of blunt force.
  • A pure bruise lies beneath an intact epidermis.
  • Bruises are caused by damage to veins, venules, and small arteries.
  • The usual bruise from a blunt impact is situated in the subcutaneous tissues, often in the fat layer. (Because of the greater volume of soft subcutaneous tissue in fat people, they tend to bruise more easily than thin ones).

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Abrasion - Also known as gravel rash; It is the destruction of skin, which usually involves superficial layers of epidermis only.

Option C - Laceration - It is the tears or split of skin and underlying tissue produced by application of blunt force to the broad area of the body, which stretches the tissue beyond the limits of their elasticity.

Option D - Stab wound - When force is delivered along the long axis of a narrow pointed object such as knife, sword etc.

KEY TAKEAWAYS - contusion is characterized by the infiltration of extravasated blood into the subcutaneous and/or subepithelial tissues. It results from the rupture of small blood vessels due to the application of blunt force.

TAGLINE: EASY

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page number:184

questions.text: Identify the plant which produces a deliriant toxin.
questions.solution:
The given plant is Erythroxylum coca.

Cocaine is the principal alkaloid found in the cultivated varieties of coca.

  • Characteristic PM findings in chronic cocaine poisoning:
  • Black tongue and teeth
  • Magnan symptoms/cocaine bugs-tactile hallucinations, also known as formication.
  • Nasal and palate perforation
  • Gangrene of nose tip, ear pinna etc

Incorrect Options:

Option B and C - Datura and hyoscine - Presents as dry mouth, delirium, dry hot skin, dilated pupils, drowsiness and death due to respiratory failure.

It is known as stupefying agent.

Option D - Aconite - Also known as meetha zeher, characteristically causes Tingling followed by numbness of mouth and throat

It also causes Hippus - Alternate contraction and dilatation of pupil.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Triad of cocaine abuse involves nasal/palatal perforation, black tongue and gangrene of peripheries.

TAGLINE: EASY

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page number:602

questions.text: You are posted as an intern in casualty when an MLC case is brought by the police with the following appearance. She was declared brought dead. What would you mark as the likely cause of death before sending the patient for postmortem?
questions.solution:
• Drowning is a form of asphyxia resulting from aspiration of fluid into air passages caused by submersion of water or other fluids.
  • External findings -
  • Fine, white tenacious copious froth that doesn't rapidly collapse and reappear after being wiped out.
  • It is the most important finding suggestive of Antemortem drowning.
  • Cutis anserina -goose skin
  • Cadaveric spasm- It is the surest sign of antemortem drowning.
  • Washer woman hands- Skin of the limbs become sodden and wrinkled.

Incorrect Options -

Option B- Hanging-It is a form of asphyxia caused by suspension of body by ligature that encircles the neck.

  • Complete hanging: Body is completely
  • Incomplete hanging: Part of the body is in contact with the ground or other surface.

Option C-Strangulation -It is the constriction of neck by means rather than suspending the body ,it can be ligature strangulation or by hands-manual strangulation/throttling.

Option D-Traumatic asphyxia -Mechanical fixation of chest by unyielding substance /object leading to respiratory failure.

Intense cyanosis and congestion above the level of compression is a characteristic feature.


Masque ecchymotique-

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Drowning is a form of asphyxia resulting from aspiration of fluid into air passages caused by submersion of water or other fluids.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page number:364

questions.text: While performing an autopsy on a burn victim, the following cutaneous findings were noted. What is the term used to describe these burns?
questions.solution:
• Filigree burn or arborescent burn or Lichtenberg's flower or feathering is a finding in burns due to lightning.
  • The fern-like pattern of erythema in the skin indicates the path taken by the electrical discharge. It usually occurs over the shoulder or the flanks within an hour of the injury and disappears in a day or two.
  • It occurs due to the rupture of small vessels and is seen in a fern-like pattern or the branching of a tree.

Incorrect Options-

Option A- Crocodile burns- Caused by high tension current burns causing multiple spark lesions.


Option B: When the skin is in firm contact with an electrical conductor, splitting of the layers of the epidermis or those of the epidermal-dermal junction occurs. This may in turn produce a raised blister known as a Joule burn.


Option C-Spark lesions are seen when contact is less firm or a narrow air gap exists between the skin and conductor.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Filigree burn or arborescent burn or Lichtenberg's flower or feathering is a finding in burns due to lightning.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page number:331

questions.text: What does the observation of contracted hands with no primary relaxation during a post-mortem examination indicate?
questions.solution:
• Cadaveric spasm, or cataleptic rigidity, occurs when the muscles that are contracted during life become stiff and rigid immediately after death, without passing into the stage of primary relaxation.

  • The spasm originates by normal nervous stimulation of the muscles and hence, is usually limited to a single group of involuntary muscles and frequently involves the hands.
  • It is caused due to ATP depletion.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A - Rigor Mortis: Rigor Mortis, also called death stiffening or cadaveric rigidity, is a state of stiffening of muscles, sometimes with slight shortening of the fibers. There is individual cell death that occurs when rigor mortis sets in. It affects all muscles in the body including voluntary and non-voluntary, contracted or uncontracted, unlike cadaveric spasms.
  • Option B - Livor Mortis: Livor Mortis, or post-mortem hypostasis, is the purplish discoloration of skin in the dependent parts of the body caused by the collection of blood in those parts due to gravitational pull. The purplish color is due to the deoxyhemoglobin.
  • Option D - Algor Mortis: Algor Mortis is the cooling of the body post death. The body does not follow Newton's law when losing temperature. The fall in temperature is because of the cessation of heat production by the somatic cells of the body.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Postmortem changes include immediate changes (somatic death), early changes (cellular death), and late changes (putrefaction and skeletonization).

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page number:163

questions.text: Police brought a person from the railway track with features of dry dilated pupil, dry skin, slurring of speech, altered sensorium. The poisoning is?
questions.solution:
• Datura is a plant known for its anticholinergic properties. It can cause symptoms of anticholinergic toxicity, which include dry skin, dilated pupils (mydriasis), slurred speech, and altered sensorium. This is consistent with the clinical presentation described.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A - Morphine:
  • Morphine is an opioid and typically causes miosis (constricted pupils), not mydriasis. It can lead to respiratory depression and altered sensorium, but the dry skin and dilated pupils are not characteristic of morphine poisoning.
  • Option B - Cannabis:
  • Cannabis can cause altered sensorium and slurred speech but is not associated with dry skin or dilated pupils. Cannabis effects are typically less severe and do not match the full clinical picture described.
  • Option D - Alcohol:
  • Alcohol can cause altered sensorium and slurred speech, but it is not associated with dry skin or dilated pupils. Alcohol typically causes miosis and does not have the anticholinergic effects seen with Datura.

KEY TAKEAWAYS-Datura poisoning causes anticholinergic symptoms, including dry skin, dilated pupils, slurred speech, and altered sensorium.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page number:598

questions.text: A-patient with previous history of abdominal surgery comes to hospital with abdominal pain and fever. X-ray of abdomen is shown below. This corresponds to?
questions.solution:
The patient need not prove negligence in case where the rule of "res ipsa loquitur" applies, which means ''the thin or facts speaks for itself'.

The patient has to merely state what according to him was the act of negligence. Conditions to be satisfied:

(1) that in the absence of negligence, the injury would not have occurred ordinarily;

(2) that the doctor had exclusive control over the injury-producing instrument or treatment;

(3) that the patient was not guilty of contributory negligence. This enables the patient's lawyer to prove his case without medical evidence.

Option B: Res judicata, i.e., if a question of negligence against a doctor has already been decided by a Court, the patient cannot contest the same in another proceeding on the same set of facts. Only appeal can be made. Limitation: A case should be filed within 2 years from the date of alleged negligence. Where breach of duty to provide care as per a contract between a patient and a doctor is committed, legal action can be initiated up to 3 years from the date of alleged negligence

Option C: NOVUS ACTUS INTERVENIENS: A person is responsible not only for his actions, but also for the logical consequences of those actions. This principle applies to cases of assault and accidental injury. Sometimes, such a continuity of events is broken by an entirely new and unexpected happening due to negligence of some other person. In such cases, the assailant will not be fully responsible for the ultimate harm.

Option D: VICARIOUS LIABILITY: (Liability for act of another): An employer is responsible not only for his own negligence, but also for the negligence of his employees, if such acts occur in the course of the employment and within its scope, by the principle of respondent superior (let the master answer).

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Res Ipsa Loquitur - Facts speak for themselves.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page number:38

questions.text:
Match the following snakes with their names:
A-Common cobra
B- Common krait
C- Russel's viper
D- Python
questions.solution:
A) Common cobra -hood present, spectacle mark present


Common krait- jet black snake with white stripes-


C) Russel's viper - has 3 rows of marking, vasculotoxic snake


D) PythoN


E) Saw scaled viper- saw shaped


Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page number:565

questions.text: Identify the type of injury
questions.solution:
Lacerations are tears or splits of skin, mucous membrane, muscle or internal organs produced by application of blunt object to broad area of the body, which crushed or stretched tissues beyond the limits of their elasticity. They are also called tears or ruptures.

Option B :An incised wound (cut, slice) is a clean cut through the tissues, which is longer than it is deep. It has length rather than depth and tends to gape. It is produced by the pressure and friction against the tissue by an object having a sharp-cutting edge, such as knife, razor, scalpel, scissors, sickle, glass, cleaver, sword, etc. In this, the force is applied over a very narrow area, corresponding with the cutting edge of the blade.

Option C :CHOP WOUNDS: They are deep gaping wounds caused by a blow with the sharp-cutting edge of a fairly heavy weapon, like a hatchet, an axe, sword, broad heavy knife, or a meat cleaver. The dimensions of the wound correspond to cross section of penetrating portion of blade.

Option D :A stab wound is produced when force is delivered along the long axis of a narrow or pointed object, such as knife, dagger, nail, needle, spear, arrow, screwdriver, etc. into the depths of the body, that is deeper than its length and width on surface of skin.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Lacerations are tears or splits of skin, mucous membrane, muscle or internal organs produced by application of blunt object to broad area of the body, which crushed or stretched tissues beyond the limits of their elasticity. They are also called tears or ruptures.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page number:190
